> --- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@> wrote:=

> >
> > Olaf -
> > 
> > THanks for the contributions!
> > 
> > What would =
you think about recasting the Filters as DecideRules?
> > 
> > Filters have=
 historically been prone to confusion: are they "filtering
> > in" or "filt=
ering out", or more concretely, what does 'true' mean?
> > 
> > It's varied=
 in different settings -- sometimes 'true' means 'exclude'
> > and others '=
include' -- and thus some filters have an
'if-match-return'
> > capability =
to make them usable in a reverse sense. But that can just
> > add to the nu=
mber of things you need to keep track of; even
experienced 
> > crawl opera=
tors at IA often get these backwards.
> > 
> > DecideRules add a little mor=
e complexity but are more explicit in
their
> > intended effects:
> >   - t=
hey answer ACCEPT, REJECT, or PASS
> >   - by chaining them, with some PASS=
es, they can achieve most of the
> same
> >     results that would require =
deep nesting of binary filters (with
> >     logical combiners like AND/OR)=

> >   - in chains, the last non-PASS decision 'wins'
> >   - by convention=
, pairs of DecideRule implementations are used,
instead
> >     of a settin=
g that inverts their conditional
> > 
> > An illustrative example is the di=
fference between URIRegExpFilter, and
> > the pair of DecideRules MatchesRe=
gExpDecideRule and
> > NotMatchesRegExpDecideRule.
> > 
> > With URIRegExpF=
ilter, you can answer only true or false. You need to
> > consider what ans=
wer the context requires, and via the
'if-match-return'
> > setting, you ca=
n control whether a regex match means 'true' or
'false'.
> > 
> > But it's =
quite likely that the regex is not the final word -- if it
> > matches, the=
 URI is 'out', but if it fails to match, the URI may not
> > necessarily be=
 'in' or 'out' -- other rules then kick in. So the 
> > non-match answer ha=
s to be logically combined with other filter
results.
> > 
> > With the Mat=
chesRegExpDecideRule or NotMatchesRegExpDecideRule,
you can
> > arrange for=
 any of the following four possibilities:
> > 
> > ACCEPT if matches, PASS =
otherwise
> > REJECT if matches, PASS otherwise
> > ACCEPT if not matches, =
PASS otherwise
> > REJECT if not matches, PASS otherwise
> > 
> > The named=
 return values constrain the usage context to interpret the
> > answer in a=
 certain way -- no "does true mean 'include' or 'exclude'
> > here?" confus=
ion -- and the PASS lets one rule of a group contribute
> > nothing to the =
final decision, if its condition isn't met. (No
need to 
> > wrap it in a A=
ND/OR to express operator intent.)
> > 
> > (By prepending such a rule with=
 an all-ACCEPT or all-REJECT rule, you
> > can set a 'default' answer for P=
ASS.)
> > 
> > So that DecideRules can be used anywhere Filters were, there=
 is a 
> > DecidingFilter class, which lets (chains of) DecideRules be used=
 to 
> > render a Filter true/false response. But we generally prefer to us=
e 
> > DecideRules in new contexts, and if there's a new CrawlURI-test to b=
e 
> > implemented, would like it implemented as a DecideRule rather than a=
 
> > Filter. Then it can be used in Filter contexts (via
DecidingFilter) a=
nd 
> > DecideRule contexts.
> > 
> > Does that make sense?
> > 
> > - Gord=
on @ IA
